text: welcome to this session of analyzing AWS
wav logs using cloudwatch logs insights
and contributor insights
hello my name is pranesh cheraj and I'm
a senior technical account manager here
at AWS cloudwatch logs insights enables
you to query and analyze your wav log
data in Amazon Cloud watch logs
you can use sample queries or write your
own custom queries to identify potential
issues and validate deployed fixes
cloudwatch contributor insights enables
you to analyze wav log data and create
time series that displays top and
contributors based on different fields
in web logs such as IP addresses user
agent host and terminating rules first
navigate to AWS cloudwatch log groups
console
select create log group
give the Law Group a descriptive name
please note for Waf logging the log
group name should start with
aws-waf Dash logs Dash prefix followed
by a name of your choice
choose the retention settings based on
your requirements and select create
navigate to the AWS web console and
select web ACLs
then select the region containing your
Waf resource
select the web basil that you want to
enable logging then go to logging and
metrics and then select enable
in the edit login page select cloudwatch
logs log group as the logging
destination and select the created log
group
if you want to redact any fields or
filter web requests then select the
settings as necessary and Save
now the wav logs are set up to send to
the specified log group in cloudwatch
logs
log analysis can be done within wav
console by going to web ACLS under AWS
web
select your web ACL and then cloudwatch
log insights alternatively you can
analyze the logs in AWS cloudwatch
console as well by going to login sites
under logs by selecting your log group
for the sake of this demo let's analyze
the logs using cloudwatch log insights
from within the wav console
in the query editor you can select one
of the saved queries or sample query
templates or write your own custom
queries to filter the wav logs
for this demo let's take an example
scenario that some of your legit client
requests are blocked by vaf and you
wanted to pass through the vaflogs to
find out why those requests are blocked
and identify any false positives so that
you can fine tune your wav rules if
those requests are actually legit
this logs inside's query will summarize
all the blocked requests for a selected
time period by client IP addresses URI
and match Rule and sort the results by
request count
please note
custom queries can only be saved for
future use in logs insights in
cloudwatch console
this concludes the demo for cloudwatch
logs insights
let's move on to the next part of the
demo analyzing web log data using
cloudwatch contributor insights
first let's go to cloudwatch console and
choose contributor insights and then
choose create rule
the rule definition choose wizard
under law groups select the name of the
wav log group that you created earlier
in the rule type choose sample Rule and
select any sample rule under web logs
for this demo I am selecting top
countries you could also create your own
rules from scratch
for the log format
you have the option to choose Json or
common log format for this demo I'm
going to choose Json
for aggregation
you can choose how you want these
contributors to be ranked
for this demo I am choosing count
then select next
for rule name enter a name
enable rule state select next
review changes and select create rule
as you can see the created rule lists
the top countries where the requests are
originating from as well as the number
of requests from each country within the
selected time period
this contributor insights will come in
very handy to find the top n
contributors especially during a dras
event response or live traffic analysis
also it can be added to a dashboard and
it is plotable as a metric that can be
alarmed on
so now you know how to set up cloudwatch
logging for wav logs and analyze them
using cloudwatch logs insights and
contributor insights
thanks for watching and happy cloud
computing from all of us here at AWS
